title: 105_s1725
content: The Act is titled the "Office of Surgeon General Sunset Act" and includes definitions. The "Office of Surgeon General Sunset Act" defines key terms such as Assistant Secretary, Federal agency, function, office, and Office of the Assistant Secretary. SEC. 3. TERMINATION AND TRANSFER OF FUNCTIONS. The Office of the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service and the position of such Surgeon General are terminated. All functions previously exercised by the Surgeon General are transferred to the Office of the Assistance Secretary for Health. SEC. 4. DETERMINATIONS OF CERTAIN FUNCTIONS BY THE OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET. The Office of Management and Budget will determine any functions transferred under section 3. SEC. 5. DELEGATION AND ASSIGNMENT. SEC. 5. DELEGATION AND ASSIGNMENT. The Assistant Secretary may delegate functions to designated officers and employees as necessary. No delegation relieves the Assistant Secretary of responsibility. SEC. 6. REORGANIZATION. The Assistant Secretary has the authority to reorganize the Office, allocate functions among officers, establish or discontinue organizational entities as needed. They can also create rules and regulations and transfer appropriations and personnel. SEC. 8 of the Act transfers personnel, assets, funds, and liabilities to the Office of the Assistant Secretary. Unexpended funds must be used for their original purposes. SEC. 9 covers additional incidental transfers. SEC. 9 authorizes the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to make necessary determinations and dispositions of personnel, assets, liabilities, grants, contracts, and funds related to transferred functions. The Director shall also terminate affairs of entities affected by the Act. The Act allows for the transfer of personnel without separation or reduction in grade for one year. Those holding Executive Schedule positions will continue to be compensated at not less than their previous rate. The Act allows for the transfer of personnel without separation or reduction in grade for one year. Positions appointed by the President with Senate consent, whose functions are transferred by the Act, will terminate on its effective date. SEC. 11. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. Continuing Effect of Legal Documents: Orders, rules, permits, agreements, contracts, licenses, and other administrative actions issued by the President or Federal agencies in functions transferred under this Act will remain in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials. The provisions of this Act shall not affect any proceedings or applications pending before the Office of the Surgeon General at the time this Act takes effect. Orders issued in such proceedings shall continue until modified or revoked by authorized officials or by operation of law. The Act does not affect ongoing proceedings before the Office of the Surgeon General. Any suits or actions initiated before the Act's effective date will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. Actions involving the Office of the Surgeon General or its officers will not be dismissed due to the Act. Administrative actions related to regulations by the Office of the Surgeon General can be continued by the Office of the Assistant Secretary with the same effect as if the Act had not been enacted. SEC. 12. SEPARABILITY. If a provision of this Act is deemed invalid, it will not affect the rest of the Act. SEC. 13. TRANSITION. The Assistant Secretary can use resources from the Office of the Surgeon General for a smooth transition. SEC. 14. REFERENCES. SEC. 14. REFERENCES. Reference in any other Federal law, Executive order, rule, regulation, or delegation of authority, or any document of or relating to the Surgeon General and the Office of the Surgeon General shall now refer to the Assistant Secretary for Health and the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Health of the Department of Health and Human Services. SEC. 15. SAVINGS. Any remaining funds for the Office of the Surgeon General in fiscal year 1998 will be transferred to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for child immunization programs. SEC. 16. ADDITIONAL CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Assistant Secretary will prepare and submit a legislative proposal to Congress for technical amendments. Within 6 months of this Act, the implementing bill must be submitted. Sections 204 and 205 of the Public Health Service Act are repealed, and Section 202 is amended by removing and redesignating paragraphs. The Public Health Service Act is amended by redesignating paragraphs and amending Section 206(a) to change references from the Surgeon General to the Chief Medical Officer. SEC. 17. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will take effect when the current Surgeon General resigns, is terminated, or when their term expires.
